intro: Mentha longifolia var. sedunensis, commonly known as the Siberian mint, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its aromatic, slightly minty leaves that are lanceolate in shape and have a textured surface. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers arranged in dense clusters, which bloom in late summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for rocky or alpine gardens. Its essential oils contain menthol and other volatile compounds, contributing to its use in traditional medicine and aromatherapy.
